tit.cmt: The actual name of the domain seems to have been "Kameyama" so I have changed the heading to reflect this. Information such as what province it was in would naturally come within the text itself.

sen.j: 亀山藩（かめやまはん）は江戸時代に丹波国にあった藩のうちの一つ。
sen.e: The domain of Tamba-Kameyama was a domain located in the Province of Tamba during the Edo period.
The Kameyama Domain was a feudal domain in Tamba Province during the Edo period.
The Kameyama Domain was a feudal domain in Tanba Province during the Edo period.

sen.j: 現在の京都府亀岡市を拠点とした。
sen.e: It was based in present Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture.
It was located in present-day Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture.
It was located in present-day Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 山陰道の入り口に当たるため、江戸幕府から特に重要視された。
sen.e: Kameyama was highly valued by the Edo shogunate as the gateway to the San'in-do.
Kameyama was greatly valued by the Edo shogunate as it served as the gateway to a region of Japan known as the San'in-do.
Kameyama was greatly valued by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) as it served as the gateway to a region of Japan known as the Sanin-do.
sen.cmt: shogunate→bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) San'in-do→Sanin-do

sen.j: 明治時代に亀山の地名を亀岡に改称したため亀岡藩（かめおかはん）とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: Kameyama was renamed Kameoka in the Meiji era, so it was also called the domain of Kameoka.
As Kameyama was renamed Kameoka in the Meiji period, the area is also known as the Kameoka Domain.
As Kameyama was renamed Kameoka in the Meiji period, the area is also known as the Kameoka Domain.

sen.j: 藩庁は亀山城 (丹波国)。
sen.e: The seat of the domain was in the Kameyama Castle (the Province of Tamba).
Kameyama Castle (Tamba Province) was the domain's seat of power.
Kameyama Castle (Tanba Province) was the domain's seat of power.

sen.j: 明智光秀は織田信長より丹波攻略を命じられると、まず亀山盆地に進出する。
sen.e: When Mitsuhide AKECHI got the order of the conqering of theTamba region from Nobunaga ODA, he immediately advanced into the Kameyama Basin.
When Mitsuhide AKECHI was ordered to conquer theTamba region by Nobunaga ODA, he first advanced into the Kameyama Basin.
When Mitsuhide AKECHI was ordered to conquer the Tanba region by Nobunaga ODA, he first advanced into the Kameyama Basin.

sen.j: 天正5年（1577年）に丹波亀山城を築いて入部したのが、亀岡の近世的な始まりといわれる。
sen.e: In 1577, Mitsuhide entered the domain for the first time building the Tamba-Kameyama Castle, which marked the beginning of the early-modern times of Kameoka.
In 1577, Mitsuhide entered the domain and built the Tanba-Kameyama-jo Castle, marking the beginning of the early-modern times of Kameoka.
In 1577, Mitsuhide entered the domain and built Tanba-Kameyama-jo Castle, marking the beginning of the early-modern times of Kameoka.
sen.cmt: 構文に問題。“Tanba-Kameyama-jo Castle” の前の定冠詞 "the"は不要。

sen.j: 天正7年（1579年）に波多野秀治が討たれて丹波が織田領になると、その功績により光秀は信長より近江国坂本城と丹波1国の領有を許された。
sen.e: When Mitsuhide defeated Hideharu HATANO in 1579, and Tamba belonged to the Lord of ODA, he was permitted to possess the Sakamoto Castle in the Province of Omi and the whole Province of Tamba by Nobunaga because of his military achievement.
When Mitsuhide defeated Hideharu HATANO in 1579 and Tanba was ceded to Nobunaga ODA, Nobunaga gave him Sakamoto-jo Castle in Omi Province and the whole of Tanba Province for his military achievement.
When Mitsuhide defeated Hideharu HATANO in 1579 and Tanba was ceded to Nobunaga ODA, Nobunaga gave him Sakamoto-jo Castle in Omi Province and the whole of Tanba Province for his military achievement.

sen.j: しかし天正10年（1582年）6月、光秀は本能寺の変を起こして信長を殺し、自らも信長の家臣・羽柴秀吉（豊臣秀吉）に討たれ、明智氏は滅亡した。
sen.e: However, causing the Honnoji Incident and killing Nobunaga in June, 1582, Mitsuhide himself was defeated by Nobunaga's vassal, Hideyoshi HASHIBA (Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI), which resulted in the downfall of the Akechi Family.

In June 1582 Mitsuhide caused the Honnoji Incident and killed Nobunaga, but was himself defeated by Nobunaga's vassal, Hideyoshi HASHIBA (Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI), a defeat which led to the demise of the Akechi clan.

In June 1582 Mitsuhide caused the Honnoji Incident and killed Nobunaga, but was himself defeated by Nobunaga's vassal, Hideyoshi HASHIBA (Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI), a defeat which led to the demise of the Akechi clan.

sen.j: その後の清洲会議で羽柴秀吉が織田氏の主導権を握ると、亀山城は信長の四男で秀吉の養子となっていた羽柴秀勝（於次）が入城する。
sen.e: After the Kiyosu Meeting, Hideyoshi HASHIBA took the initiative in the Oda Family, and subsequently, Hidekatsu HASHIBA (Otsugi), Nobunaga's fourth son and Hideyoshi's adopted child, entered Kameyama-jo Castle.

In the subsequent Kiyosu Meeting, Hideyoshi HASHIBA seized power from the Oda Family, and Hidekatsu HASHIBA (Otsugi), Nobunaga's fourth son who had beed adopted by Hideyoshi, then entered the Kameyama-jo Castle.

In the subsequent Kiyosu Meeting, Hideyoshi HASHIBA seized power from the Oda clan, and Hidekatsu HASHIBA (Otsugi), Nobunaga's fourth son who had been adopted by Hideyoshi, then entered the Kameyama-jo Castle.

sen.j: 天正13年（1585年）に秀勝が早世すると、秀吉の甥に当たる豊臣秀勝（小吉）が代わって入部した。
sen.e: When Hidekatsu died young in 1585, Hideyoshi's nephew, Hidekatsu TOYOTOMI (Kokichi), entered the domain instead.
When Hidekatsu died young in 1585, Hideyoshi's nephew, Hidekatsu TOYOTOMI (Kokichi) took over the domain.
sen.cmt: 入部 has been translated as "entered… for the first time" but from the context, it seems that "take over" or something similar is more appropriate.
sen.e: When Hidekatsu died young in 1585, Hideyoshi's nephew, Hidekatsu TOYOTOMI (Kokichi) took over the domain.

sen.j: 天正18年（1590年）に徳川家康が関東に移封されたため、豊臣秀勝が甲斐に入部することになると、様々なな武将が短期間で入れ替わりした。
sen.e: As Ieyasu TOKUGAWA was transferred to a new domain in the Kanto Region, and Hidekatsu TOYOTOMI entered a new domain in Kai, many other warlords changed their fiefs in a short period of time.
In 1590, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA was transferred to a new domain in the Kanto Region, and Hidekatsu TOYOTOMI took over Kai, whereupon various other warlords came and went in a short period of time.
sen.cmt: The last section of this sentence is not talking about warlords changing their fiefs, but rather of comings and goings in the Kameyama region.
sen.e: In 1590, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA was transferred to a new domain in the Kanto Region, and Hidekatsu TOYOTOMI took over Kai, whereupon various other warlords came and went in a short period of time.

sen.j: 秀吉の甥で養子となった羽柴秀秋（小早川秀秋）もその1人である。
sen.e: Hideaki HASHIBA (Hideaki KOBAYAKAWA) who was Hideyoshi's nephew and his adopted child was one of these.
Hideaki HASHIBA (Hideaki KOBAYAKAWA) who was Hideyoshi's nephew and another one of his adopted children was one of these.
sen.cmt: Added "another one of his adopted" for clarity.
sen.e: Hideaki HASHIBA (Hideaki KOBAYAKAWA) who was Hideyoshi's nephew and another one of his adopted children was one of these.

sen.j: 文禄4年（1595年）に豊臣政権下の京都所司代であった前田玄以が亀山城に入部する。
sen.e: In 1595, Gen'I MAEDA who was the Kyoto Shoshidai, or Governor, under the Toyotomi regime entered Kameyama-jo Castle for the first time.
In 1595, Gen'I MAEDA who was the Kyoto Shoshidai, or Governor, under the Toyotomi regime took over Kameyama-jo Castle.
In 1595, Geni MAEDA who was the Kyoto Shoshidai, or Governor, under the Toyotomi regime took over Kameyama-jo Castle.

sen.j: 慶長5年（1600年）、関ヶ原の戦いでは前田玄以はやむを得ず西軍に加わったが、家康に西軍の情報を内通していたため、戦後に家康より所領安堵を受け、ここに丹波亀山藩が成立した。
sen.e: In the battle of Sekigahara in 1600, because Gen'I MAEDA who had unwillingly joined the Western Forces was secretly in touch with Ieyasu, he could receive the reassurance of the domain after the battle; thus, the domain of Tamba-Kameyama was established.

At the battle of Sekigahara in 1600, Gen'I MAEDA who had unwillingly joined the Western Forces was secretly in touch with Ieyasu and was given assurances that he would receive the domain after the battle; thus, the domain of Tanba-Kameyama was established.

At the battle of Sekigahara in 1600, Geni MAEDA who had unwillingly joined the Western Forces was secretly in touch with Ieyasu and was given assurances that he would receive the domain after the battle; thus, the domain of Tanba-Kameyama was established.

sen.j: 慶長7年（1602年）5月、前田玄以が死去すると、後を子の茂勝が継いだが、茂勝は丹波八上藩に移封され、丹波亀山藩は天領となる。
sen.e: After the death of Gen'I MAEDA in May, 1602, his son, Shigekatsu, succeeded him, but Shigekatsu was transferred to the new domain of Tamba-Yakami, and consequently, the domain of Tamba-Kameyama became a shogunal demesne (the territory held directly by the Tokugawa shogun).

After the death of Gen'I MAEDA in May 1602, his son, Shigekatsu, succeeded him, but Shigekatsu was transferred to the new domain of Tanba-Yakami, and the Tanba-Kameyama Domain became a shogunal demesne (a territory held directly by the Tokugawa shogun).
sen.cmt: Removed "consequently". The domain did not become a demsme as a consquence of Shigekatsu being transferred.
sen.e: After the death of Geni MAEDA in May 1602, his son, Shigekatsu, succeeded him, but Shigekatsu was transferred to the new domain of Tanba-Yakami, and the Tanba-Kameyama Domain became a shogunal demesne (a territory held directly by the Tokugawa shogun).

sen.j: 慶長14年（1609年）、徳川氏譜代の家臣である岡部長盛が下総山崎藩から移封され、丹波亀山藩が再立藩された。
sen.e: As Nagamori OKABE, a retainer of the daimyo in hereditary vassalage to the Tokugawa house, was transferred from the domain of Shimosa-Yamazaki to Kameyama, the domain of Tamba-Kameyama was reestablished.
When Nagamori OKABE, a hereditary vassal of the Tokugawa house, was transferred from the Shimosa-Yamazaki Domain to Kameyama, the Kameyama Domain was reestablished.
sen.cmt: Not sure about the translation of 徳川氏譜代の家臣. Wouldn't this be OK as "a hereditary vassal of the Tokugawa house"?
sen.e: In 1609, when Nagamori OKABE, a hereditary vassal of the Tokugawa house, was transferred from the Shimousa-Yamazaki Domain to Tanba-Kameyama, the Tanba-Kameyama Domain was reestablished.

sen.j: 長盛が亀山藩に入ったのは、大坂藩の豊臣秀頼への対策の1つでもある。
sen.e: Nagamori's entering of the domain of Kameyama was one of the measures for Hideyori TOYOTOMI in the domain of Osaka.
Having Nagamori take over the Kameyama Domain was one of the measures against Hideyori TOYOTOMI in the Osaka Domain.
sen.cmt: It seems to me that this talking about the Tokugawa shogunate trying to control Hideyori, and so I have used "against Hideyori".
sen.e: Having Nagamori take over the Kameyama Domain was one of the measures against Hideyori TOYOTOMI in the Osaka Domain.

sen.j: 慶長15年（1610年）、西国大名を総動員して、亀山城の築城が始まった。
sen.e: In 1610, the construction of the Kameyama Castle began with the combined efforts of all the daimyo of western provinces.
In 1610, the construction of the Kameyama Castle began with the combined efforts of all the daimyo of western provinces.
In 1610, the construction of Kameyama Castle began with the combined efforts of all the daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) of western provinces.
sen.cmt: 構文に問題。 “ Kameyama Castle” の前の定冠詞 "the"は不要。

sen.j: 元和 (日本)7年（1621年）、三河国西尾藩より大給松平家の松平成重が2万2,000石で亀山藩主となる。
sen.e: In 1621, Narushige MATSUDAIRA of the House of Ogyu-Matsudaira from the domain of Nishio in the Province of Mikawa became the lord of the domain of Kameyama with 22,000 koku.
In 1621, Narushige MATSUDAIRA of the House of Ogyu-Matsudaira from the Nishio Domain in Mikawa Province became the lord of the Kameyama Domain with assigned revenues of 22,000 koku.
sen.cmt: Clarified what is meant by "with 22,000 Koku."
sen.e: In 1621, Narushige MATSUDAIRA of the Ogyu-Matsudaira family from the Nishio Domain in Mikawa Province became the lord of the Kameyama Domain with assigned revenues of 22,000 koku.

sen.j: 寛永11年（1634年）、近江膳所藩より菅沼定芳が4万1,000石で入るが、第2代藩主・菅沼定昭が嗣子無くして慶安元年（1648年）に死去し、菅沼氏は改易となる。
sen.e: In 1634, Sadayoshi SUGANUMA entered Kameyama with 41,000 koku, but the second lord, Sadaakira SUGANUMA had no heir and died in 1648, and consequently, the Suganuma clan forfeitetd their territories.

In 1634, Sadayoshi SUGANUMA from the Zeze Domain in Omi Province took over Kameyama with assigned revenues of 41,000 koku, but the second lord, Sadaakira SUGANUMA had no heir and died in 1648, and consequently, the Suganuma clan forfeitetd their territories.
sen.cmt: Clarified what is meant by "with 41,000 koku."
sen.e: In 1634, Sadayoshi SUGANUMA from the Zeze Domain in Omi Province took over Kameyama with assigned revenues of 41,000 koku, but the second lord, Sadaakira SUGANUMA had no heir and died in 1648, and consequently, the Suganuma clan forfeited their territories.

sen.j: 代わって藤井松平家の松平忠晴が3万8,000石で入るが、第3代藩主の松平忠周の時代に武蔵国岩槻藩へ移封となる。
sen.e: Tadaharu MATSUDAIRA of the House of Fujii-Matsudaira entered Kameyama with 38,000 koku instead, but the family was transferred to the domain of Iwatsuki in the Province of Musashi during Tadachika MATSUDAIRA's time.

Tadaharu MATSUDAIRA of the House of Fujii-Matsudaira then took over Kameyama with assigned revenues of 38,000 koku, but the family was transferred to the Iwatsuki Domain in Musashi Province in the era of Tadachika MATSUDAIRA.
sen.cmt: Clarified what is meant by "with 38,000 koku."
sen.e: Tadaharu MATSUDAIRA of the Fujii-Matsudaira family then took over Kameyama with assigned revenues of 38,000 koku, but the family was transferred to the Iwatsuki Domain in Musashi Province in the era of Tadachika MATSUDAIRA.

sen.j: 貞享2年（1685年）、備中国庭瀬藩より5万石で久世重之が入るが、短期間で三河吉田藩へ移封となる。
sen.e: In 1685, Shigeyuki KUZE entered Kameyama with 50,000 koku from the domain of Niwase in the Province of Bicchu, but the family was soon transferred to the domain of Mikawa-Yoshida.

In 1685, Shigeyuki KUZE took over Kameyama with assigned revenues of 50,000 koku from the Niwase Domain in Bicchu Province, but the family was soon transferred to the Yoshida Domain in Mikawa Province.
sen.cmt: Clarified what is meant by "50,000 koku."
sen.e: In 1685, Shigeyuki KUZE took over Kameyama with assigned revenues of 50,000 koku from the Niwase Domain in Bicchu Province, but the family was soon transferred to the Yoshida Domain in Mikawa Province.

sen.j: 元禄10年（1697年）、美濃国郡上藩より井上正岑が4万7,000石で入るが、これも短期間で常陸国下館藩へ移封される。
sen.e: In 1697, Masamine INOUE entered Kameyama with 47,000 koku from the domain of Gujyo in the Province of Mino, but his family was also transferred to the domain of Shimodate in the Province of Hitachi soon.

In 1697, Masamine INOUE from the Gujo Domain in Mino Province took over Kameyama with assigned revenues of 47,000 koku, but his family was also quickly transferred, in their case to the Shimodate Domain in Hitachi Province.
sen.cmt: Clarified what is meant by "with 47,000 koku."
sen.e: In 1697, Masamine INOUE from the Gujo Domain in Mino Province took over Kameyama with assigned revenues of 47,000 koku, but his family was also quickly transferred, in their case to the Shimodate Domain in Hitachi Province.

sen.j: 元禄15年（1702年）9月7日、遠江国浜松藩から青山忠重が5万石で入るが、第3代藩主・青山忠朝の時代に丹波篠山藩へ移封というように、藩主家が定着しなかった。
sen.e: In September 7, 1702, Tadashige AOYAMA entered Kameyama with 50,000 koku from the domain of Hamamatsu in the Province of Totomi, but the lord family did not last long in such a way that the third lord, Tadatomo AOYAMA was transferred to the domain of Tamba-Sasayama.

In September 7 1702, Tadashige AOYAMA from the Hamamatsu Domain in Totomi Province took over Kameyama with assigned revenues of 50,000 koku, but the family did not stay long, the third lord, Tadatomo AOYAMA being transferred to the Sasayama Domain in Tanba Province.
sen.cmt: Clarified what is meant by "with 50,000 koku."
sen.e: In September 7, 1702, Tadashige AOYAMA from the Hamamatsu Domain in Totomi Province took over Kameyama with assigned revenues of 50,000 koku, but the family did not stay long, the third lord, Tadatomo AOYAMA being transferred to the Sasayama Domain in Tanba Province.

sen.j: 寛延2年（1749年）、青山氏と入れ替わりで形原松平家の松平信岑が亀山藩主となると、以後はこの家系が代々の亀山藩主として定着した。
sen.e: After Nobumine of the House of Katahara-Matsudaira became the lord of the domain of Kameyama in 1749 instead of the Aoyama Family, the Matsudaira Family lasted as the lord of the domain of Kameyama for generations.
After Nobumine of the House of Katahara-Matsudaira replaced the Aoyama clan as the lord of the Kameyama Domain in 1749, the House of Matsudaira Family took charge for generations.
After Nobumine MATSUDAIRA of the Katahara-Matsudaira family replaced the Aoyama clan as the lord of the Kameyama Domain in 1749, Matsudaira family took charge for generations.

sen.j: 慶応4年（1868年）の戊辰戦争では新政府の山陰鎮撫使に降伏する。
sen.e: In the Boshin War of 1868, the domain of Kameyama surrendered to the repression delegate of the new government.
In the Boshin War of 1868, the Kameyama Domain surrendered to an agent of the new government.
sen.cmt: "repression delegate" sounds a bit unnatural" How about simply "an agent"
sen.e: In the Boshin War of 1868, the Kameyama Domain surrendered to an agent of the new government.

sen.j: 明治2年（1869年）、亀岡藩と改称する。
sen.e: In 1869, it was renamed the domain of Kameoka.
In 1869, it was renamed the domain of Kameoka.
In 1869 it was renamed the domain of Kameoka.

sen.j: 明治4年（1871年）7月、廃藩置県で亀岡県となる。
sen.e: In July, 1871, the domain of Kameoka became Kameoka Prefecture by the abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures.
In July 1871, with the abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures, the domain of Kameoka became Kameoka Prefecture
In July 1871, with the abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures, the domain of Kameoka became Kameoka Prefecture.

sen.j: 11月に京都府に吸収された。
sen.e: In November, 1871, it was incorporated into Kyoto Prefecture.
In November, 1871, it was incorporated into Kyoto Prefecture.
In November 1871 it was incorporated into Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 歴代藩主
sen.e: The chronological list of lords
List of Lords of the domain in chronological order
The chronological order of the Lords.
sen.cmt: フィードバックにより統一しました。

sen.j: 前田（まえだ）家
sen.e: The Maeda Family
The Maeda Family
The Maeda Family

sen.j: 外様。
sen.e: The tozama daimyo (the allied daimyo of the Tokugawa shogun)
The tozama daimyo (the allied daimyo of the Tokugawa shogun)
The tozama daimyo (the allied daimyo of the Tokugawa shogun)

sen.j: 5万石。
sen.e: 50,000 koku
50,000 koku
50,000 koku

sen.cmt: ハイフンの前後にスペース挿入

sen.j: 前田玄以（げんい）
sen.e: Gen'I MAEDA
Gen'I MAEDA
Geni MAEDA

sen.j: 前田茂勝（しげかつ）
sen.e: Shigekatsu MAEDA
Shigekatsu MAEDA
Shigekatsu MAEDA

sen.j: 岡部（おかべ）家
sen.e: The House of Okabe
The House of Okabe
The Okabe family

sen.j: 譜代。
sen.e: The fudai daimyo (the daimyo in hereditary vassalage to the Tokugawa house)
The fudai daimyo (the daimyo in hereditary vassalage to the Tokugawa house)
The fudai daimyo (the daimyo in hereditary vassalage to the Tokugawa house)

sen.j: 3万2千石。
sen.e: 32,000 koku
32,000 koku
32,000 koku

sen.cmt: ハイフンの前後にスペース挿入

sen.j: 岡部長盛（ながもり）〔従五位下、内膳正〕
sen.e: Nagamori OKABE [Jyugoige-Naizen-no-kami, Director of the Imperial Cuisine with Junior Fifth-Low Court Rank]
Nagamori OKABE [Jyugoige-Naizen-no-kami, Director of the Imperial Cuisine with Junior Fifth-Low Court Rank]
Nagamori OKABE [Jyugoige-Naizen-no-kami, Director of Imperial Cuisine, (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade)]
sen.cmt: ”with”の削除。 ”Director of the Imperial Cuisine with Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade” ->Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Gradeを持ったDirector of the Imperial Cuisin ということか。その場合は “Director of Imperial Cuisine, (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade)”

sen.j: 松平（大給）（まつだいら（おぎゅう））家
sen.e: The House of Matsudaira (Ogyu)
The House of Matsudaira (Ogyu)
The Matsudaira (Ogyu) family
The fudai daimyo of 22,000 koku (1621-1634)
The fudai daimyo of 22,000 koku (1621-1634)
The fudai daimyo of 22,000 koku (1621 - 1634)
sen.cmt: ハイフンの前後にスペース挿入

sen.j: 松平成重（なりしげ）〔従五位下、右近将監〕
sen.e: Narishige MATSUDAIRA [Jyugoige-Ukon'no-jyo, Captain of the Imperial Guard of the Right with Junior Fifth-Low Court Rank]
Narishige MATSUDAIRA [Jyugoige-Ukon'no-jyo, Captain of the Imperial Guard of the Right with Junior Fifth-Low Court Rank]
Narishige MATSUDAIRA [Jugoinoge Ukon no jo, Captain of the Imperial Guard of the Right, (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade)]
sen.cmt: ”with”の削除。(Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade)に統一

sen.j: 松平忠昭 (大給松平家)（ただあき）〔従五位下、信濃守〕
sen.e: Tadaaki MATSUDAIRA (the House of Ogyu-Matsudaira) [Jyugoige-Shinano-no-kami, Governor of the Province of Shinano with Junior Fifth-Low Court Rank]
Tadaaki MATSUDAIRA (the House of Ogyu-Matsudaira) [Jyugoige-Shinano-no-kami, Governor of the Province of Shinano with Junior Fifth-Low Court Rank]
Tadaaki MATSUDAIRA (the Ogyu-Matsudaira family) [Jugoinoge Shinano no kami, Governor of Shinano Province, (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade)]
sen.cmt: ”with”の削除。.-> “... Shinano. (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade)”

sen.j: 菅沼（すがぬま）家
sen.e: The House of Suganuma
